name: src/Deferred.js
Deferred
description:
bluebird dropped `defer()`, see

http://bluebirdjs.com/docs/api/deferred-migration.html

i think it's still really useful as a structure for when you need to store
handles to reject and resolve to be called later.

name: src/array.js
asArray
description:
If `subject` is an {@link Array}, return it. Otherwise return a new Array
containing only it.
todo:
Only deals with {@link Array} *exactly*. Might want to think about 
  {@link Set} and others?

params.name: subject
params.description: Value that may be a single element or an array of elements.

return.description: `subject` or an new array of only `subject`.

name: eachAsArray
description:
Treat `subject` as an Array whether it is or not - if `subject` is an 
{@link Array} invoke `iteratee` on each element. Otherwise just invoke 
`iteratee` on `subject` itself.

Like `_.each(asArray(x), f)` but avoids the allocation of a new array when
`x` is not one.

Except... `iteratee` should be only relied on to be invoked with 
`(element, index)`, since creating the array that would go in the third
position pretty much defeats the purpose. If you need that reference just
use `_.each(asArray(x), f)`.

params.name: subject
params.description: Array to iterate over or non-array to invoke on.

params.name: iteratee
params.description: Function to invoke on each element.

name: mapAsArray
description:
Treat `subject` as an Array to be mapped over, whether it is or not.
If `subject` is an {@link Array}, map `iteratee` over the elements.
Otherwise just invoke `iteratee` on `subject` itself and return an array
with only it in it.

Like `_.map(asArray(x), f)` but avoids the allocation of a new array when
`x` is not one.

Except... `iteratee` should be only relied on to be invoked with 
`(element, index)`, since creating the array that would go in the third
position pretty much defeats the purpose. If you need that reference just
use `_.map(asArray(x), f)`.

params.name: subject
params.description: Array to iterate over or non-array to invoke on.

params.name: iteratee
params.description: Function to invoke on each element.

name: src/env.js
DEFAULT_ENV
description: the default environment returned by {@link .env} when none is set.

name: isBrowser
description:
determine if we're in the browser by seeing if the top-level object is
`window`.

return.description: true if we're in a browser environment.

name: isNode
description: determine if we're in node by seeing if the top-level object is `global`.

return.description: true if we're in a node environment.

name: IS_BROWSER
description: constant that is the result of calling {@link isBrowser} on import.

name: IS_NODE
description: constant that is the result of calling {@link isNode} on import.

name: env
description:
the *environment* dictates how things are built and behave
(versus "app instance", which declares *where* it's running / what it's
doing -- see {@link .appInstance}).

the value is read from the `NODE_ENV` environment variable at 
`process.env.NODE_ENV` on the server and from `window.ENV` on the client.

if neither of these are found, throws a {@link StateError}.

the environment can be set to anything, though unless you have given
considerable through and uncovered sufficient reason, it should probably 
be one of:

1.  `development` (default)
2.  `production`
3.  `test`

libraries and apps can of course respond to these values however they like,
but the general thematic should follow:

1.  **`development`** (default)
    
    built and configured for development and debugging. this env
    should make it as easy as possible to work on the app, at the 
    expense of performance.
    
    things we expect in the development environment:
    
    -   lots of logging available.
        -   means [metalog][] is not stripping anything accept
            perhaps `trace` logging at compile time (via `.babelrc`
            config -- can still filter in runtime of course).
    -   quick and clear access to source code.
        -   no [minification][] or concatenation.
        -   source maps where necessary.
    -   tcomb type checking
        -   tcomb skips most checks in `production` mode by default, but it
            should be checking and throwing errors when things fail in 
            `development`.
    -   fail early and often
        -   while it makes sense to try and continue on in `production`, when
            in `development` anything unexpected should throw an error
            immediately.
   
2.  **`production`**
    
    built and configured for performance.
    
3.  **`test`**
    
    the environment set inside testing processes (mocha or whatever else).
    
    generally the same as `development`, with potential modifications to 
    support testing. 
    
    be aware that if testing frameworks are using ES2015+ source they will
    be doing the transformation under the `test` environment, and be sure
    to cover it in `.babelrc` if using `env` switching.

[minification]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minification_(programming)
[metalog]: https://github.com/nrser/babel-plugin-metalog

throws.description: if we can't determine that we're in a node or browser environment.

name: appInstance
description:
the *app instance* is an identifier for *where* the app is deployed that 
build settings and runtime behavior can be dependent on. it is read from
the `NODE_APP_INSTANCE` environment variable on the server

name: src/errors/BaseError.js
_inherits
description:
adapted from Meteor's
{@link https://github.com/meteor/meteor/blob/release/METEOR%401.4.0.1/packages/meteor/helpers.js helpers.js}
and used to make {@link BaseError} extend {@link Error}.

Sets child's prototype to a new object whose prototype is parent's
prototype.
examples:
<caption>Used as:</caption>
Meteor._inherits(ClassB, ClassA).
_.extend(ClassB.prototype, { ... })

Inspired by CoffeeScript's `extend` and Google Closure's `goog.inherits`.

name: name
description: "name" of the error.

name: constructor
description: BaseError constructor.

KeyError

name: src/errors/NotImplementedError.js

name: src/index.js
src/lodash.js
src/match.js
src/metalogger/Level.js
src/metalogger/LevelSpec.js
src/metalogger/Logger.js
DATE_FORMAT_TOKENS
description:
tokens in date format string are replaced with result of calling
the function with the date.

name: formatDate
description:
format a date according to a format string, see `.DATE_FORMAT_TOKENS` for
the available tokens.

name: formatHeader
description:
format a header according to a format string, see `.HEADER_FORMAT_TOKENS`
for the available tokens.

name: formatLevel
description: the string output of the level.

name: formatDelta
description:
formats a delta in ms for output.

when:

-   delta is undefined (first message), returns "+----ms"
-   the delta is 9999 or less, returns something like "+0888ms"
-   the delta is over 9999, returns "+++++ms"

name: formatPath
description: formats the path consisting of filename, parentPath and line for output.

name: pushSpec
description:
adds a spec to the end of the specs array (least priority).
returns the spec.

name: unshiftSpec
description:
adds a spec to the beginning of the specs (highest priority).
returns the spec.

name: notify
description: sends a system notification if the node-notifier package is available.

name: specFor
description:
find the active level spec given spec query properties from a log message, 
which is the first spec for which `LevelSpec#match` returns true.

- query: SpecQuery


returns `undefined` if no spec matches.

name: levelFor
description: get the level from the spec for a query, if any match.

name: shouldLog
description:
determines if a message should be logged given level and spec query info
by finding the applicable level spec and seeing if it's level is

name: log
description: log a message unless filtered by a level spec.

name: getDelta
description:
gets the ms since the last message was logged, or undefined if it's the
first.

name: getConsoleFunction
description: get the proper `console.*` function for the log level.

name: logInNode
description:
log the message in node, where we don't need to fuck with
values vs. references like we do on the browser since it get spits out
text at that time. we also have colors there (easily).

gonna try out the `print` npm package for display.

https://www.npmjs.com/package/print

name: logInBrowser
description:
log the message in the browser, where we want to log the actual
objects so we can explore them in the console, but usually want to log
snapshots of the values as they were at the times they were logged.

name: src/metalogger/index.js
src/metalogger/snapshot.js
Stack
description:
take a baseClone of an object so that it can be explored in the browser
in the state is was **at the time**.

pretty much lodash's cloneDeep changed to not just return empty objects when
it can't clone something.

name: argsTag
description: `Object#toString` result references.

name: cloneableTags
description: Used to identify `toStringTag` values supported by `_.clone`.

name: SNAPSHOT_REF
description: used to wrap an un-clonable value so we know

name: baseClone
description:
The base implementation of `_.clone` and `_.cloneDeep` which tracks
traversed objects.

params.name: stack
params.description: Tracks traversed objects and their clone counterparts.

name: src/object.js
groupByEach
description:
like lodash/underscore `groupBy` but the iteratee (called `getGroups` here)
should return an array of string group names and the value will be added to
**all** those groups in the result.

name: insert
description:
Set `keyPath` to `value` in `object` only if the key does not exist. The key
path must be completely absent -- if it is set to `undefined` or `null` 
an error will still be thrown.

**Mutates `object`.**

name: assemble
description:
Shallow merges `objects` together into a new {@link Object} as long as there
are no conflicting keys.

name: need
description:
gets the value at a key path from an object, throwing `KeyError`
if the result is `undefined`.

properties.name: defaultValue
properties.description: Value to default to if `keyPath` is not found.

name: procure
description:
A pickier [_.pick][] -- throw a {@link KeyError} if any of `paths` are 
missing.

[_.pick]: https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#pick

name: mapDefinedValues
description: map values but drop keys where the mapped value is undefined.

name: src/path.js
NormPath
description:
A normalized path is a path that is either:

-   Exactly `.`.
-   Has no `.`, `..` or empty segments.

Intended to represent the return type of [path.normalize][].

[path.normalize]: https://nodejs.org/api/path.html#path_path_normalize_path

name: tNormPath
description: tcomb type for {@link NormPath}.

name: AbsPath
description:
An absolute path, per Node's [path.isAbsolute][],
which returns `false` for tilde paths (`~/...`).

[path.isAbsolute]: https://nodejs.org/api/path.html#path_path_isabsolute_path

name: tAbsPath
description: tcomb type for {@link AbsPath}.

name: ResolvedPath
description:
A resolved path is a path that is absolute and normalized, as returned from
Node's [path.resolve][].

[path.resolve]: https://nodejs.org/api/path.html#path_path_resolve_path

name: tResPath
description: tcomb type for {@link ResPath}.

name: TildePath
description:
A tilde path is a string that starts with '~', which we interpret like the
shell to mean the current user's home directory.

name: tTildePath
description: tcomb type for {@link TildePath}.

name: PathSegment
description:
A piece of a path... which is a string that doesn't have the path 
separator character in it.

name: tPathSegment
description: tcomb type for {@link PathSegment}.

name: PathSegments
description: Many pieces of paths.

name: tPathSegments
description: tcomb type for {@link PathSegments}.

name: Dir
description:
A path that we know is a directory because it's last segment
is empty, `.` or `..`.

name: tDir
description: tcomb type for {@link Dir}.

name: NormDir
description: A normalized directory - a {@link Dir} that is also a {@link NormPath}.

name: tNormDir
description: tcomb type for {@link NormDir}.

name: AbsDir
description: An absolute directory - a {@link Dir} that is also a {@link AbsPath}.

name: tAbsDir
description: tcomb type for {@link AbsDir}.

name: ResDir
description: An resolved directory - a {@link Dir} that is also a {@link ResPath}.

name: tResDir
description: tcomb type for {@link ResDir}.

name: TildeDir
description:
A directory relative to the user's home via starting with `~` -
a {@link Dir} that is also a {@link TildePath}.

name: tTildeDir
description: tcomb type for {@link TildeDir}.

name: split
description: Split a path by the system path separator.

name: expand
description:
Like {@link Path.resolve} but it expands tilde paths to the user's home
directory.

params.name: paths
params.description:
Paths to expand. Joins them from last backwards until am absolute path is
  formed, otherwise assumes relative to {@link process.cwd}.

name: commonBase
description:
Find the common base path. Expands paths before comparison, and doesn't 
consider '/' to be common because it is shared between *all* unix-y file
paths, making it a bit pointless.

name: toDir
description: Make a path string into a {@link Dir} by appending `/` to it if needed.

name: resolveDir
description:
Resolve paths and apply {@link toDir} to the results to get a {@link ResDir}.

**NOTICE** 

Unless you explicitly *don't* want tilde (`~/...`) expansion you probably
want to use {@link expandDir}, which expands paths that start with `~` to
the current user's home direcotry.

name: expandDir
description: Expand paths and apply {@link toDir} to the results to get a {@link ResDir}.

print

params.name: showArrayIndices

params.name: showArrayLength

params.name: sortProps
params.description: Alphabetise the enumerable properties of printed objects

name: out
description: Wrapper for console.log(print())

name: commonPrefix

gets the common prefix for an array of strings, which will be '' if they
don't have any.
